Create Reports

Source: R/report.R
report.Rd

Create textual reports. See the documentation for your object's class:

  • Dataframes and vectors

  • Correlations and t-tests (htest)

  • ANOVAs

  • (General) Linear models (glm and lm)

  • Mixed models (glmer and lmer)

  • Bayesian models (stanreg and brms)

report(model, ...)

Arguments

model

Object.
...

Arguments passed to or from other methods.

Examples

library(report)

model <- t.test(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data = iris[1:100, ])
r <- report(model)
#> Warning: Argument 'pooled' is deprecated, use 'paired' instead. Setting paired <- pooled.
#> Warning: Argument 'pooled' is deprecated, use 'paired' instead. Setting paired <- pooled.

# Text
r
#> The Welch Two Sample t-test suggests that the difference of Sepal.Length by Species (mean in group setosa = 5.01, mean in group versicolor = 5.94) is significant (difference = -0.93, 95% CI [-1.11, -0.75], t(86.54) = -10.52, p < .001) and can be considered as very large (Cohen's d = -2.26)., The Welch Two Sample t-test suggests that the difference of Sepal.Length by Species (mean in group setosa = 5.01, mean in group versicolor = 5.94) is significant (difference = -0.93, 95% CI [-1.11, -0.75], t(86.54) = -10.52, p < .001) and can be considered as very large (Cohen's d = 0.95)., The Welch Two Sample t-test suggests that the difference of Sepal.Length by Species (mean in group setosa = 5.01, mean in group versicolor = 5.94) is significant (difference = -0.93, 95% CI [-1.11, -0.75], t(86.54) = -10.52, p < .001) and can be considered as very large (Cohen's d = -2.80). and The Welch Two Sample t-test suggests that the difference of Sepal.Length by Species (mean in group setosa = 5.01, mean in group versicolor = 5.94) is significant (difference = -0.93, 95% CI [-1.11, -0.75], t(86.54) = -10.52, p < .001) and can be considered as very large (Cohen's d = -1.72).
summary(r)
#> The Welch Two Sample t-test suggests that the difference of Sepal.Length by Species is significant (difference = -0.93, 95% CI [-1.11, -0.75], p < .001, Cohen's d = -2.26)., The Welch Two Sample t-test suggests that the difference of Sepal.Length by Species is significant (difference = -0.93, 95% CI [-1.11, -0.75], p < .001, Cohen's d = 0.95)., The Welch Two Sample t-test suggests that the difference of Sepal.Length by Species is significant (difference = -0.93, 95% CI [-1.11, -0.75], p < .001, Cohen's d = -2.80). and The Welch Two Sample t-test suggests that the difference of Sepal.Length by Species is significant (difference = -0.93, 95% CI [-1.11, -0.75], p < .001, Cohen's d = -1.72).
